text: Probably the perfect work perfume. The opening prepares you for a bright, bitter morning, while the dry down is comforting and personal towards the end of the day. It smells sharp and cognitive, gentle and polite at the same time. It's a memorable, unique fragrance that doesn't smell anonymous like a lot of other perfumes recommended for work. My boyfriend thinks it smells exactly like cut ivy; I think the green colour perfectly represents its smell.
author: violetsforyourfurs

text: Chanel N19 EDP hits me sharp and peppery before settling into iris: dry, a bit oily-creamy, almost like cold lipstick pressed against stone. It‚Äôs sharp but elegant, with moss cutting through, very dry and chalky, like clean dust on stone. It feels sculptural, cool, even a little severe. It is iris, moss, resins and woods stripped of any sweetness. Even that peppery bite adds to that icy atmosphere. Oddly, it‚Äôs comforting in how serious and unsentimental it is.
author: FlaconNoir

text: This definitely has the strong characteristic DNA of Chanel - very earthy, patchouli-like, and green. This opens dirty, like unwashed vegetables, and stays that way. An acquired taste.
author: Liddywinnie

text: What a shame! Chanel how dare you to ask that much money for scented water in the nowadays version. Today i have tested this Chanel no19 at Ici Paris. It was the eau de parfum. Exactly after 10 minutes of applying the parfum was completely gone on my wrist. Nothing to smell. I have had the same experience with the nowadays version of no.5. In my opinion you can better buy a dupe of these parfums. They are much cheaper and probably much more long lasting. Chanel is probably thinking our name sells itself so we can weaken all the parfums more and more. I just can't believe such a marketing. Big big shame on you Chanel. ü§ÆThe perfume blast in the beginning is very nice and very green thats all. Ten minutes of smell voor ‚Ç¨150.
author: Dollycat

text: I had a bizarre experience sampling this - I wore Chanel No. 19 on one arm and Chanel Chance Splendide on the other. And the contrast was... unsettling. No. 19 was so grounding and transcendental. Splendide, by comparison, felt so banal it made me wince. I‚Äôve tested No. 19 before, but this time I gave it my full attention. I slowed down and let it unfold, every nuance. It‚Äôs green and soapy, yes, but that doesn‚Äôt begin to capture the energy it holds. It‚Äôs cool but not cold. Detached, but not indifferent. This is a scent that doesn‚Äôt chase trends. There‚Äôs something Chanel does when it‚Äôs at its best: it creates a feeling of absolute self-possession. No. 19 has that in spades, it doesn‚Äôt flirt, and it doesn‚Äôt beg to be liked. It's classic, composed, and full of depth. In that strange comparison with Chance Splendide, it felt like two entirely different brands. No. 19 reminded me why I believe in Chanel in the first place.
author: MetaMystic

text: another surprise in my collection! now I have been thinking about the age of this particular bottle. it can be at least ten years old, but in the same stride twenty. I remember it well from 1974. perhaps many people think 'how does he come so precisely with 1974 ?'. well in march 1975 we (my twinbrother and me) started with the study (= working) of Nurse. in fact we started in aug.1974 as Aids in the Ward's Kitchen for half a year. so I really see myself in that particular perfumery sniffing the then important perfumes. I guess there was still a little Staid athmosphere. what I remember of No19 is that it was there in Eau de toilette and in Parfum. and I just braced myself for a Bitter and Countering Opening. I could have sworn there would be Galbanum in it. I just saw it is a Note in the 'Perfume'. here we have the famous 'Green Notes'. where it now may seem that I am not satisfied about the perfume (i.e. Edp) I may have used the wrong words. I find this a beautiful perfume and am amazed how well-blended it is and how it then still succeeds to have the austere opening. in fact there is a kind of 'institutionalized' austerity which is, after all, the Hallmark of No19. and all the Chypres of this era. with my perfume I am struck on how facetted and wonderfully striated it is, this all in Glissements and Fluidums. perhaps there is the Green Phase (the Opening) with [quasi-] Galbanum then Green Notes, the Bergamot must do a Freshening-Up (Fresh-Up the most revolting and dreaded product of male cosmetics) but alas I do never smell individual Citruses only in Colognes which are not my cup of tea entirely. but Hesperidic and Incisively Green it is, the opening, also with Neroli Flowers. then we get a phantastic Middle phase. (I already noted the perfume lasts for hours.) it is all Lovely Flowers, notably Iris, Rose, Narcissus, Lily of the Valley and Ylang-Ylang. these phases do not clash with each other, because of the quality ingredients their botanical and aromachemical features all seem to usurpate each other where in the Middle Phase the Flowers just arrive and the more fleeting Green Notes are (not entirely) disappearing. Henri Robert was the originator of the 1971 Chanel No19 and it is my guess either Jacques and or Son Olivier Polge took care of the following editions. the base notes are all sturdy and grounding this Chypre in Leather, Oakmoss, Sandelwood and Vetiver. it is the Woody Backbone with typical Chanelissime. yet I am compelled to judge this perfume as a whole, as it has just become that in my collection. a Supremely Blended, Exquisitely Present perfume for those who want to maintain personal space and Chicness.
author: jaguarundina

text: The perfume which I can't match. It has its own character. The top of the perfume is dry, green, almost bitter. Iris consumes it after a while and the floral heart is more polite but there is a wildreness still. With mossy base, earthy and leather, it provokes. It is disturbing - for me, this scent isn't meditative, calm or natural. I found it bold and sharp, although it has a vintage spirit. Clearly it is a legend-loved or hated, but never indifferent... --- Strong projection, amazing longevity (8 hours and still very fresh...).
author: Shui-Xian

text: Such in interesting fragrance. On first spray, I got the classic Chanel dna, which somewhat reminded me of my vintage No 5 Eau de Cologne. Yet, it takes a different turn. Ronin. Jones‚Äô review is pretty spot on! I get a classic vibe from this. It evokes a memory that I can‚Äôt place. Perhaps someone I knew many many years ago wore this. It‚Äôs beautiful in a slightly vintage way however it doesn‚Äôt necessarily smell dated. Past the opening, I actually don‚Äôt find this all that green, as it settles into a warm woody base with a touch of freshness. Eight hours later it is so beautiful ! Great for all seasons and occasions.
author: Ismellgood2024

text: that opening of the starchy rooty iris and the bitter, stemy, vegetal greeness of the galbanum is really interesting. which then reveals a chypre core as it settles down. consisting of dewy, fresh and silky complex melange of florals, a soft oakmossy base, with a little squeeze of citrus to brighten everything. its well-blended, clean, soft, powdery, a bit soapy, but never sharp. i dont find it aloof and cold as others describe it. i find it easy to wear and approachable. like a very warm and friendly wealthy middle aged woman. that mid and drydown is honestly underwhelming. the mix of the florals and citrus reminds me of a body lotion or a face cream the longer it stays on my skin. i need something more earthy and bitter
author: ronin.jose

text: This and No.19 Poudr√© is what I imagine Heaven smells like. Green floral with a gorgeous woody base that melds with your skin. There's aldehydes, but I think it's just Chanels base or DNA. I discovered this when Chanel still made tiny 5ml bottles and sold them in places like K-Mart (remember them?). I was like 15 and didn't want to be seen with my mom shopping so I went to the jewelry department and they kept them in a turning glass tower. Chanel meant fancy, lol, so I bought it. I don't think it's an exaggeration to say I fell in love. This is green to me, but the woody base is what woody bases should smell like, not the screechy messes we have in today's fragrances. Chanel has done an amazing job of hanging on to its identity. This won't please a lot of people today, it's not easy, sweet or trendy but it's perfume in a time when a house perfumer just throws vanilla in a base and calls it a day.
author: Clws

text: My Mum's signature perfume since I was a kid. On her it smells very warm and elegant. Reading the notes I'm surprised that the top notes are green, which makes sense, but on my mother's skin chemistry it dries down into a scent that makes me think of white (the colour she wears the most) amber, and clean, expensive warm clothing. Never sharp or heavy. I don't think of the scent of old fashioned (like some of the reviews mention) but it's definitely a woman's perfume. I myself wouldn't try wearing it until I'm a bit older and wiser lol. It smells good on me also, but I just get the impression I can't carry it yet.
author: kiki-alice

text: Today I get play one of my favorite games: a multi format vintage vs. new comparison. The beautiful lady walking arm-in-arm with me today is none other than No. 19. On the back of my left hand and that wrist is an EdC from probably the late 1970s/early 80s, on the upper part of that arm is a new EdP, and on my right hand and arm is an extrait from the early 1990s. Sometimes I feel like the luckiest guy in the world. Curiously, No. 19 doesn't get much love, in fact it seems to get quite a bit of hate. I've heard some people say that if No. 19 was a woman, she would be a frigid "b" with no friends. Though I understand what they're saying, I think that's overly harsh and a classic case of being misunderstood. To me this character is more prim and proper rather than cold and mean; it's the difference between us loud and brash Americans versus British royalty, let's say: just because the Brit royalty is typical stiff-upper-lip and very proper doesn't make them cold and mean. This difference of character perception can also be seen across the formats and vintages I'm wearing today. Take my very old EdC vs. the new EdP as an example: though age has most assuredly tempered Ms. 19 in the EdC format, that hyper green claw-like galbanum top note is far smoother and well-rounded in the EdC than the EdP. The EdP is claws out, right from the get-go, and, as you would expect, those claws stay out for longer. Rather quickly, the EdC dries down to a very pleasant and soft powdery woody floral chock full of iris, lily, sandalwood, and oakmoss (real oakmoss - have I mentioned how much I love opportunities to smell real oakmoss?) - making this the easiest of the No. 19s to wear, and that's really the whole story of the EdC beyond this point. The EdC is desperately pretty, calm, and friendly after the last dry down and for the few hours beyond. After about an hour after application, the EdP's claws are still out but they've been filed down, and it's definitely more apparent that the use of synthetics is more prominent in this new EdP versus the old EdC. This is as you would expect, but I must emphasize that the "synthetic" quality of the EdP is more than you would expect. Now, I have a different frame of reference here because I'm smelling a very old EdC side-by-side with the new EdP, so don't take my comments to mean that the new EdP has an offputting fake quality to it, because it still smells amazing; if you don't have an old formulation to compare it to, you are likely not going to notice the synthetics much. The filed-down claws of the EdP that I mentioned are no longer in the form of a sharp green galbanum, but vivid, saturated, thorny florals. The EdP is all about the heart notes of rose, a rooty iris, jasmine, lily, and ylang ylang - but, again, be careful when you go in for a sniff or you reach your hand into that bouquet because there are thorns there. These aren't gentle florals by any means; they aren't going to actively scratch you, but they are fully capable of defending themselves if needed. Ms. 19 is no longer in fight-or-flight mode, but she still has her guard up. Those ylang-ylang and jasmine notes in the EdP are a tour de force team, all vivid and saturated colors of white, green, and yellow. But what about the extrait?! Yes, I know you want to know what the extrait is doing. Frankly, I'm at a loss for words with the extrait, but I shall try. It is just so, so, so good. Absolutely stunning. The extrait opened with the same hyper green galbanum note of the others - the EdP more specifically - but the galbanum is not claws-out like it is in the EdP. There are no claws here. The galbanum's personality is softened and gentrified by some of the most beautiful jasmine, iris, ylang-ylang and rose notes you will ever smell. Every note of the EdP (and EdC for that matter) are presented and accounted for in the extrait, but if I were to rate the materials/accords on realism, quality, and execution, the extrait would be 10 out of 10 while the EdP and EdC make do at 6. I love the EdC and the EdP, so this should hopefully place in understandable context just how good I think the extrait is. While the EdC and the EdP are playing around, drying down and doing there thing, at nearly three hours in the extrait is only just warming up. Remember what I said about No. 19 being prim and proper and not cold and mean? Picture then a beautiful, regal, proud and strong woman in the finest handmade dress and you have the extrait. Monica Belucci in Valentino, basically; the extrait smells the way she looks. It will be a couple hours more even at this point before the extrait begins moving, after the EdC and the EdP have mostly worn themselves out. One curiosity to definitely note, and it should also be mentioned it's quite a hot day here in my part of California, the bergamot and neroli of the extrait have a far greater voice on the blotter than they do on my skin. The same could be said for the EdP as well, but the voices of the bergamot and neroli of the extrait are still greater than that of EdP's. We're going to fast forward to the end of the day, many hours later. The EdC is long gone, the EdP is a very pleasant skin scent of soft sandalwoods and much more pronounced notes of vetiver and animalic musks than the EdC. And the extrait... it's still there. While I'm worn out from an afternoon of running around, this lovely lady on my arm is still there, energized, and ready for an evening soiree. The galbanum and florals are gone, but the vetiver, woods, and mosses are still going. Partly why the extrait is my favorite of the No. 19 formats is because Chanel have made it act like a proper extrait should. While the EdC and EdP tire themselves out in hours, launching themselves into the air and drying-down like they're in a race (a bit exaggerated, but you get my point), the extrait stays close to you. Very close. Insanely powerful, but close. That measured approach to its energy and output, like a real extrait in the classical style should be, is exemplary to the personality I find in Ms. No. 19. She's not cold and mean, she's elegant, proud, strong, and confident - with you for the long haul, so to speak. Those are my favorite kinds of people. And that's why No. 19 is very likely my favorite Chanel perfume.
author: Nathan86

Maybe rotten plants or somethjng but that‚Äôs as far as it goes. Try something from Emil Elise, Kenzo or Marc jacobs daisy line if you want somethjng truly fresh and vibrant green üåøüå±
author: Yila

text: Love love love! I don‚Äôt understand why aldehydes aren‚Äôt listed in the scent profile. They are the most prominent note. Chanel 19 is like if Chanel 5 gave birth to itself in the woods‚Ä¶ it rolled around in the leaves and mossy forest floor. I‚Äôm a huge fan of Chanel 5, it‚Äôs my signature fragrance. And I‚Äôve worn it for almost 30 years with a little break for some time when I didn‚Äôt wear anything while working in the health field. But I‚Äôm back! I bought Chanel 19 on a blind buy. I really love all Chanel fragrances and they are, by far, my favorite house. I assumed I‚Äôd like 19 and took a chance. I‚Äôm so glad I did. Sometimes, Chanel 5 feels heavy and, on those days, I will now wear 19 as it‚Äôs a bit lighter. It is quite reminiscent of 5. It‚Äôs milder, but still the powdery aroma I love about 5. The green notes are very nice. Upon spritzing, I do smell that vintage lipstick scent that other people have mentioned and I really like it. It‚Äôs like powdery lipstick and earth. My Chanel loves are 5, Coco Noir, and now 19. These are the ones I currently own. I do love Edimbourg, but haven‚Äôt made the plunge as it‚Äôs too light and I can barely smell it on myself without putting my wrist up to my nose. And I do enjoy all the others, especially Allure, Chance Eau Splendide, Coco Mademoiselle and Coco on paper. I haven‚Äôt skin tested them yet, but have samples I plan to use. If you like aldehydes, Chanel 5, or vintage scents, you will likely love 19.
author: LaBohemeFemme

text: This is my favourite scent. I‚Äôve used it since 2008. The only thing I don‚Äôt like about is I go nose blind if I wear it every day, so I don‚Äôt get to enjoy it! Whenever I‚Äôve not worn it for a week or more, it‚Äôs such a treat because I get whiffs of fragrance all day.
author: Amonik

text: Chanel No. 19 Eau de Parfum is a green floral chypre that dares to stand apart in a world of warm and sensual perfumes. Launched in 1970 and named after Coco Chanel‚Äôs birthday, this fragrance is composed with striking confidence: a bold opening of galbanum and neroli, layered over an elegant heart of iris and rose, and resting on a refined base of vetiver, oakmoss, and leather. Its accord is uncompromisingly green and cold, aloof, almost emotionally detached yet impeccably refined. Truthfully, what I feel from this fragrance is precisely the absence of feeling; it‚Äôs a scent that wears like a porcelain mask: distant but dignified, cold but elegant not harsh, just icy in temperament. I had longed to own this scent since childhood, mesmerized by the serene green hue of its juice, yet it was never available in my home country nor in the Chanel boutiques I visited during my early travels in my childhood. Over time, I came to realize this perfume is not made for the taste of today‚Äôs youthful, modern women, and it lacks the sugar-coated femininity they often favor, and is rarely seen compared to other Chanel scents. Still, despite its emotional frostiness, I love this perfume deeply, perhaps not for what it is, but for what it meant to me as a child. Its sillage and longevity are moderate, neither overwhelming nor fleeting. And although I cherish it, I can admit there are greener, more evocative fragrances available. If not for my nostalgic connection, I might have chosen differently. Ultimately, Chanel No. 19 belongs in formal settings and the perfect companion to quiet strength and intellectual elegance. I‚Äôd rate it 6.4 out of 10.
author: Behrad

text: When I was younger, many of the current Chanel fragrances had not yet appeared. I was hesitant to wear Chanel No. 5, I thought that the wearer of this fragrance needs to grow up to perceive it correctly. The very first fragrance from Chanel, which I immediately accepted and which still remains one of my favorites is Cristalle Eau de Parfum Chanel by designer Jacques Polge. I was lucky to meet a charming girl from Bordeaux one day, we were young carefree students, having a great time together. It was she who advised me to start getting to know the Chanel No. 19 fragrance. I must say honestly that I didn‚Äôt perceive the first bottle as anything special, but the more often I used No. 19, the more I liked it. I get a lot of compliments when I wear No.19. The scent is infinitely romantic and beautiful. I like it at any time of the day or night, in any season of the year. I try to use it in special situations so that it remains for me not an everyday routine, but a constant "holiday that is always with you."
author: Gemilina

text: Married my Sweetheart 38 years ago wearing this- and he's still my Sweetheart. No. 19 is still as classy, timeless, elegant and as chic as ever. I adore it like no other.
author: lisl

text: I found this to be extremely unpleasant and old fashioned. If someone was near me and wearing this, I would hope the projection is not strong, otherwise I would need to move away. It was one of the most unpleasant fragrances I've encountered. It had a pungent, strong green smell, not a pleasant green, but overwhelming, like you'd never be able to wash it off. That said, I did not like any of the Chanel perfumes in the boutique. While they each smell different, you can tell they are from the same "family." I was hoping to like 19 because I've read on a forum, a few people say they like it. I guess either you like Chanel perfumes or you don't. They just aren't for me.

text: At first spray I was blown away, it's a world away from the heavy vintage of Chanel 5, but so distinct. author: elisa.fuentes.1

text: massimilianoinquieto12/02/24 09:55 Chanel 19 no longer has anything in common with what it was in the 70s, 80s, 90s. It cannot be said that it has been reformulated but rather changed. In the comparison there is nothing that unites them, they are just two different perfumes. The current one is also good but has nothing to do with the original Chanel 19. If a perfume was based on oakmoss, narcissus, lily of the valley, orris root, sandalwood, vetiver and galbanum, most of these natural oils were banned. Lily of the valley prohibited, oakmoss prohibited, narcissus with what it would cost to distil that flower or even just its rhizome, they don't put it there, leather feels very synthetic and strange, that is, there is nothing that resembles it anymore. The real Chanel 19 was cold, severe, masculine, reminiscent of a melancholy day with a cold, rainy sky, but in being so severe it was also comforting. I still have it so I can compare and of course I prefer vintage. The older it is, the better it is. The one now is very far away, a soapy fragrance with a touch of yellow lemon initially, much more frivolous and cheerful, it seems transparent yellow, dusty. I also find it rather strange in smell. The first note is too strange and does not conform to what it was in its original. Here the notes are felt too distinctly and it was certainly not in Chanel's perspective which instead wanted to create fragrances where the ingredients could not be smelled, like Chanel n5. Even if after a while it tends to become more "human" and is covered with yellow flowers, otherwise it is a pleasant perfume but far from what it was in its origins.
author: swedishmilk15

text: @Massimilliano, I think you meant to post that on fragrantica.it
author: genevieves

text: This review relates to the modern EDP. A gorgeous green woodsy scent, but disappointing longevity for such a price. Scarcely 3 hours on the skin for an eau de parfum, and even so, that initial, beautiful blast of green notes dry down into a far too intimate skin scent an hour or so in. Occasionally they'll be a little waft of that initial brilliance beyond an hour, but only if caught on your sleeve. Was it a bad batch? Apparently not, according to other underwhelmed reviewers of the modern incarnation. I adore the scent itself. Remarkably unisex to a modern nose, despite its waspy, ladylike connotations for some. It has a particular glamour of its own, one really quite hard to define. Perhaps indictive of the shifting cultural landscape of its early 70s inception, it rests somewhere between a put-together old aunt in a twinset and pearls and her carefree niece who likes a batwing sleeve. Next time I'll buy vintage for the longevity or see if I can secure a sample of the modern pure parfum. Quite disappointed in Chanel. One of the few designer brands I usually trust when it comes to balancing quality, longevity and price while staying true to the character and history of its older fragrances.
author: BlueMusk

text: Chanel no 19, how I've loved you for decades on end! I agree with so much of what has been written in previous posts. I wanted to add a comment without using official perfumery terminology, which is that Chanel no 19, for me, always started out to smell a bit like the liquor Gin, which has a base of Juniper berries. So, the green scent was never grassy or fern-like, but like crushed, green, Chinese Juniper berries. Extremely cooling & refreshing on a hot summer's day! Yet, Juniper berries are not on the list of ingredients. What can I tell ya? That's the forward scent which does retreat somewhat after wearing it 30 minutes or more, but still detectable & blending beautifully with all the other fragrance notes that have been well described in other posts. As others have said, Chanel 19 is indeed gorgeous and almost indefinable. So clean, light and feminine and no one will smell as wonderful as you except perhaps another woman wearing Chanel 19! I read somewhere, long ago, that it was Coco's favourite fragrance. Has anyone else heard this same thing?
author: GreenMansions

text: Chanel 19 non ha pi√π niente in comune con quello che era negli anni 70,80,90. Non si pu√≤ dire che sia stato riformulato ma proprio cambiato. Nel confronto non c'√® niente che li accomuni,sono proprio due profumi diversi. Buono anche quello attuale ma non ha niente a che vedere con lo Chanel 19 originale. Se un profumo era fondato sul muschio di quercia, narciso,mughetto, radice di iris,sandalo,vetiver e galbanum,la maggior parte di questi olii naturali √® stata vietata. Mughetto vietato,muschio di quercia proibito,narciso con quello che costerebbe distillare quel fiore o anche solo il suo rizoma,non ce lo mettono, cuoio lo sento molto sintetico e strano,cio√® non c'√® piu niente che gli assomigli. Il vero Chanel 19 era freddo,severo,maschile,ricordava una giornata malinconica di cielo piovoso e freddo,ma nel suo essere cos√¨ severo era anche confortante. Cel'ho ancora quindi posso fare il confronto e naturalmente preferisco il vintage. Pi√π √® vecchio e pi√π √® buono. Quello di adesso √® molto lontano,un fragranza saponosa con un tocco di limone giallo inizialmente,molto pi√π frivolo e allegro,sembra giallo trasparente,polveroso. Lo trovo anche piuttosto strano come odore. La prima nota risulta troppo strana e non conforme a quella che era nel suo originale. Qui le note si sentono troppo distintamente e non era certo nell'ottica di Chanel che invece voleva creare fragranze dove non si sentivano gli ingredienti, come Chanel n5. Anche se dopo un po tende a diventare pi√π "umano" e si copre di fiori gialli, per il resto √® un profumo gradevole ma ben lontano da come era alle sue origini.
author: massimilianoinquieto

text: This is really pretty, and easier to wear than I expected. I routinely find that I tend to *not* be challenged by green scents unless they're quite heavy on oakmoss, so bear that in mind. This is a pale green fragrance though, and fits the color of the liquid well. Yes...there is a fair amount of oakmoss here, but it's really tempered by the powdery soapiness of the iris. Any more oakmoss and I would probably dislike this, but it's not as dusty as many other classics tend to be. Honestly, it's similar to how Chanel includes patchouli; instead of a rough patchouli, it's often a cleaner, crisp patchouli. Well...the oakmoss is like that as well, it's not as rough or fusty, but rather kind of bitter and crisp. Hope that makes sense. Everything can be, of course (wear what you love), but I do feel like although it's about 66% classically feminine, this is also easily unisex. The lily-of-the-valley alongside the green heart notes is very reminiscent of rain, but the dry quality of iris+oakmoss balances this out. And honestly, I think although this fragrance seems incredibly semi-formal or "office-core" (as the kids say), I'd just as soon wear this on a drizzly springtime hike on the woods. Very nice. And I'm bummed that my sample was nearly empty upon arrival, so I can only test it once, since I really would love to apply this in mid-April...it feels like the heart of spring üåß üåø üå±
author: ShadowsofLight

text: Okay, I have to add an update to my previous review! Found a half full bottle of the eau de parfum (old juice) which I purchased and wow! All I can say is that Chanel 19 eau de parfum (old juice) is just as beautiful, classy and uptown as I remembered it from my younger years. Crazy the memories just a whiff brings back... I do agree with others.. the eau de toilette Chanel 19 smells quite different.. not as soft, and creamy.. definitely a missing note. Chanel 19 has always been a head turner and almost indefinable... this scent will absolutely set the wearer apart from anybody else. Love Chanel 19.
author: Amby333

text: Green notes? None here, thank GOD! "Green notes" make me think of grassy scents... THANKFULLY, there are NO grassy scents here as it settles. Maybe they're there at first? But they quickly fade upon spraying. Chanel No. 19 is truly a "vintage-lipstick and rose-cream" scent. The rose is truly a CREAMY rose, and this is what absolutely shines through. If you own No. 19 Poudre, that will be your gateway to the original No. 19... For me, this is SO much better! Chanel No. 19 Poudre has a sparkly-champagne twist to it, mixed with a dry powder aura. Its original version, Chanel No. 19, is creamy-rose made even creamier by iris and lily-of-the-valley. This is what I had always wanted No. 5 to smell like, but that one is too old lady on me (though, the spray lotion version is a lot more palatable to most). No. 19 does NOT feel vintage, it feels very new and modern to me. If you get this, literally no one will smell like you, but everyone will ask you what you're wearing because you smell so clean and pretty. As I mentioned before, there is no green once it's settled on the skin... either I don't know what people are talking about when they say green, or everyone else is crazy, LOL. To my super-smeller nose, this is all lipstick and creamy rose. The creamy part comes from the iris mixed with lily-of-the-valley, and I'm sure the gorgeous soapy-lipstick notes are from the aldehydes that Chanel is so famous for. Throw No. 5 out the window... THIS is what Chanel should be known for! No. 19 can be worn as a day-to-day scent, as it doesn't have long arms, but it DOES have a beautiful skin scent that makes you smell like you're wearing the world's best smelling lotion that lasts all day. Classy, feminine without being overpowering. Talk about a wedding fragrance!! So gorgeous. This is a stand alone fragrance, a master in its class, and if you love to smell really pretty, you should have Chanel No. 19 in your repertoire.
author: DragonflySparrow

text: Many reviews of this perfume allude to the forest or to the ‚Äúboardroom bitch‚Äù but this perfume transports me to a tennis court in the 1980‚Äôs. There‚Äôs a beautiful woman wearing a chic, white tennis-set. She‚Äôs a Beverly Hills princess that sports pearls and smokes Vogues. This perfume is icy, powdery, earthy, cold and creamy green. It‚Äôs beautiful worn in sunny weather, which helps to bring out the powder and the creamier aspect of the damp, mossy, green notes. The epitome of casual luxury, you can wear this to your Pilates class or the grocery store and feel like a million bucks. This is my first green perfume and my first Chanel, and it is unlike anything I‚Äôve worn before. It makes me feel clean, plush and expensive, like I‚Äôve just taken a luxurious bubble bath with a glass of champagne. Gorgeous.

text: Clean green soapy smell but weak projection and not very complex. I wanted to love this since everyone said it was complex but I was let down :( I enjoy the smell a lot, but it is too simple to me. I think this would work well for someone who wants an uncomplicated soapy green fragrance. It's a nice scent, but I wanted it to be different and complex but unfortunately, it fell flat on my skin. I think if you have the right skin chemistry the varying notes will be more pronounced. It is a safe blind buy if you are looking for a pleasant green soapy smell, but I will say that projection is mild and it may fall flat depending on your skin chemistry. If someone gifted me this I would be very happy, but I wouldn't necessarily go buy it myself. Overall it is nice, but didn't work with my skin, unfortunately.

text: Adding another review because I have more thoughts to add - I instantly fell in love with this fragrance, mostly for how complex it is. This is not a one trick fragrance at all, everything is there, greenery of course, but also subtle citruses, woody notes, earthy notes, florals, and the same ylang and sandalwood that is at the heart of Chanel‚Äôs No.5 This to me conjures the image of being a young child, carefully exploring through a complex of thorny bushes at the back of the garden on a humid summer‚Äôs day - I can almost hear insects buzzing.

text: I am a newbie to fragrances, but have to say i LOVE this fragrance! The last time i smelled this would have been in 1978, I‚Äôm 64 now (yes I‚Äôm old!). I never imagined i would like green fragrances, but this is very elegant, beautiful and sophisticated! It‚Äôs not screechy and I don‚Äôt find it sharp or bitter at all. It has the Chanel DNA through and through. I find it super soft and feminine. It was impossible to find somewhere that I could sample it. I tried 4 stores near me, so drove around quite a bit over a couple of days. I wanted to compare it with poudre, but can‚Äôt get to smell that anywhere! text: Tried this one and Poudr√© side by side, and while both are masterpieces, Poudr√© works better on my skin. The in store tester of Poudr√© was much more similar to the EdP than my bottle, which i liked. And I think that‚Äôs because my current bottle is old and the vanilla is therefore stronger. No 19 EdP is a nice freshie, and Poudr√© is a more feminine version. They are very similar and you don‚Äôt need both
author: Evie01

text: Update: I tried this rare gem again and I am currently deciding on whether I should get this one or another bottle of Poudr√© to wear to work after I am done with my current Poudr√© bottle It is undeniable that it is a difficult fragrance to wear because of it‚Äôs bitterness. It smells like summer where I grew up (the west coast of Sweden) with the mix of wild roses, freshly cut grass and seabreeze. I pretty much get teleported back to the seaside street close to my family‚Äôs house, where the fresh, salty winds blow against the luxury homes with their perfectly mowed lawns. Poudr√© is a completely different scent. That one is a strong grassy scent that turns into fine makeup powder. Poudr√© is stronger and ‚Äùstuffier‚Äù because of the powdery notes, which makes it a bit more youthful, girly and maybe more palatable. I find almost the same powdery drydown in Orph√©on and Lipstick Fever. I am tempted to get the EdP instead of Poudr√© because it is more unique and less ‚Äùstuffy‚Äù, but it is a challenging wear with the bitter notes that border on being dirty. In the end, I will try both of them side by side, and my skin chemistry will make the final decision. Since they only have 19 EdP and Poudr√© in large bottles, I feel like I have to really love it before making a commitment and purchasing.

text: This shines in the summer! It smells so green, powdery, luxurious, sexy. I actually like that the projection is not super big like other chanel perfumes. That adds to the classy feel this perfume embodies. I am definitely glad to have this one in my collection.
author: bagaceirababy

text: For me it is one of the most classic, elegant and sublime perfumes in the world. It is without a doubt one of my favorite Chanel perfumes. If I don't have it in my collection it is only because I have 19 Poudr√©, although they are actually quite different and this one surpasses it in performance. It is a natural, green, somewhat earthy scent, with a soapy and powdery background. It is the perfume that a forest fairy would wear when coming to us in a clair of the forest bringing a ray of sun that, filtered through the treetops, would transmit joy to us. It feels very balanced, neither the green notes nor the oakmoss nor the iris, nor certainly any of the other notes that are even more subtle and integrated into the composition, stand out too much. As for a comparison with perfumes that are said to be similar, it feels more powdery, fresh and less earthy than Silences by Jacomo. N¬∞19 Poudr√© de Chanel is somewhat sweeter and more powdery, with much more presence of the iris. Revlon's Jontu√© is much sweeter and floral, due to the effect of mimosa and ylang ylang. All four are for me quite different perfumes and they could have a place simultaneously in the collection of someone who really likes green perfumes. On my skin it has a moderate projection and lasts 9-10 hours. Scent 8.5/10 Duration 9.5/10 Sillage 7/10 Quality/price 7/10 Versatility 6.5/10 Packaging 7/10 Would I buy again? I did not buy it

text: This is good stuff. If you've ever smelled Amla Oil (green-colored oil, Indian store) it smells a bit like that. Very herbal, oily, woody, and there's a touch of powder. What a triumph!

text: I spent a truly glorious hour or so at our city's Chanel boutique, finally getting my nose on to so many scents that I've been yearning to smell for ages. So. the 19 EDP is a scent that I never got around to smelling before because I've always been a 19 EDT girl. Yes, girl - because I started wearing this scent as an older teen way back in the mid-80's and have been wearing it ever since. Unfortunately, I no longer own the vintage, and the current EDT is really something I only wear anymore out of nostalgia. It is only a shadow of its former self. Thus, I decided on this occasion to get a proper sniff of the EDP and to actually wear it to see for myself if, as some posters have written, it is better than the EDT in its current formulation. Well folks, it really is. No comparison in fact. The iris is so much more discernible in the EDP rather than just the suggestion that it is in the current EDT. In fact, every note seems truer in this version. The only thing I miss here is the hyacinth that distinguishes the EDT. Too bad I never was able to smell the EDP in its original iteration but this version is lovely in its own right. I'm about half way done with my current bottle of the EDT. When that is done I will happily go over to the EDP.

text: I love this, it's my first Chanel fragrance. I have over 250 and not one Chanel until now. I got this for my love of bitter green Galbanum. One of my favourite scents for summer is Margiela Untitled EDP, this is very similar but slightly more floral. This is definitely unisex!
author: APMM

text: Drips class and sophistication. Simply a masterpeice! This was on my wishlist l remember my mother and aunts wearing it and no 5 in the 80s and they smelled so good. I used to sneak a few squirts out of my mother's bottle it was the vintage one silver plastic square casing with the gold band round it and gold chanel disk on the top. With the removable bottle of liquid inside. I recently bought this a few days back but it was a half bottle as l saw the mossy green notes and thought maybe l won't like it now. I was wrong! This pretty green liquid has a big personality she's classy and sexy. She is better than no.5 and has more complex fragrance notes and projects further than no 5. She is liquid good breeding and class in a bottle, she rides horses and wears tweed blazers, has two carat flawless solitaire diamonds in her ears, shes a rich woman in her 50s living in a country estate mansion, shoots pheasant and mixes with royalty she's aristocratic. This perfume has those notes expected in practically everything neroli bergamot and the corresponding flowers like iris that provide the emmerging powdery phase and then just as your melting into the powdery loveliness a mossy strange note comes through that makes you wonder oh that's strange, what's that? An almost smokey type smell. Its like it shouldnt be a typically female perfume note, something masculine thats fallen into the perfume formula and no one noticed? Its strange, earthy but pleasant then you realise it's oakmoss and leather and vetiver and sandlewood giving it that masculine serious grown up edge, its like a well groomed man, a totally shaggable silver haired fox with suntanned skin and sparkling blue eyes and perfect white teeth, üòÜ ü§£ üòÇ a handsome intriguing gentleman in an expensive leather coat and italian gucci loafers (without socks) and trendy jeans and a grey cashmere sweater reading in a secondhand bookstore where you can smell his coat, his male scent, the soap he washes with and the books that have aged in this perfume and a tiny bit of cigar smoke, and oh my goodness it grows in scent and when you move about you smell these soapy, leathery, smokey, mossy, powdery, notes that smell so unusual but expensive. It smells so classy l adore it. I have immediately bought a full 100ml bottle of the EDP so I can fully abuse my half bottle and wear it constantly for a couple of months and not have to worry about it running out. It is the most gorgeous perfume. I've never smelled something so masculine but also feminine in such an exquisite way before. I'm obsessed already! I give this a 10/10

text: Christ is this beautiful, the most luxurious thing I've ever owned. It makes one want to live up to it.

text: Smells like the green offspring of of Chanel No.5 and Coco Chanel. Very powdery iris, earthy, ylang ylang, with a ton of moss and bit of leather. Not your typical fruity floral flirtatious spring-time perfume. It's more serious and mature scent. Very classic Chanel smell though. Will need to warm up to it. When I first sprayed it, I thought it smelled like gin. But the dry down is very powdery and mossy and POTENT. If you like iris, this is for you. Not sure if it's for me. Also, on a side note: I can sort of taste this perfume when I wear it though, which is weird. Maybe I sprayed too much? Update: I tried it some more and I'm disliking it more and more. I can't get past the overwhelmingly powdery iris and moss. And every single time I put it on I can literally taste it in my mouth and want to wash my mouth out. Not an inviting scent whatsoever. I would put this on if I had to be in a meeting with someone I despise. Very difficult perfume to like. Sadly had to return it.

The iris and leather are reminiscent of a rainy day in the city, while holding the sophisticated air that Chanel does best. It's Paris meets Provence meets Practical Magic.

author: Romantic1

text: I like No 19 but can't seem to find an edition that wows me. The current EDP is overpriced IMO and both current EDP and EDT do not perform as I would like. Still, I own the current No 19 EDT and enjoy it. It's good on clothes and skin but it's a luxury fragrance that one suspects Chanel has diluted. I had to wait a year for my "new" EDT to perform. My vintage EDP (20+ years) smells FANTASTIC but is a soft performer. My vintage EDT has off top notes, just as does my vintage Cristalle EDT. Perhaps the solution is a vintage that has never been opened and has been stored in it's box for two decades. H√©las, I'm not made of money. I recommend a couple dabs of pre IFRA edp then some sprays of the latest EDT on clothes and skin. I often see bottles of the new No 19 EDT on discount sites and also auction sites for half the retail price. I remind myself that No 19 wasn't designed decades ago with top notes to show off and seduce the buyer. (Or perhaps Chanel has neutered the top in recent editions.) Patience pays off. The vintage EDP enters a beautiful stage at about 2 hours. And I can smell No 19 EDT lingering, hours after, sometimes days after, in the room where I had sprayed it.
author: Myst√®res du Ch√¢teau de D√©

text: This is a very fresh and green perfume, but it has a dirty and dusty smell in the dry down that I am really not a big fan of. The opening of N¬∞19 eau de parfum is as I said very green and smells like a temperate and cool forest with its green notes, but it has a slightly citrusy and bright quality from both the bergamot and neroli and a hint of white floracy from the neroli too. The citrusy quality from the opening in N¬∞19 then dies down fairly quickly within the first hour and a half. I like the floral heart notes the most in this fragrance, but they aren't quite as amped up as I'd prefer. You can still smell the very green quality from the opening notes mixing in with the heart notes and I can smell some of the dirty quality from the oakmoss and vetiver in the base peeping through. The haylike nuances from the narcissus then emphasizes this even more unfortunately. The powdery iris and a very unripe smelling ylang ylang (in the heart notes) then wafts now and again into my nose, reminding me somewhat of Chanel N¬∞5. I can smell hints of rose and lily of the valley too, but they aren't at all prominent to me. It sort of reminds me of Ormonde Jayne for women at this stage. Finally, I can smell a very heavy, dirty, bitter, aromatic and overpowering dose of oakmoss in the dry down and it almost threatens to engulf all of the other notes in this fragrance. I can smell a strong and dusty dose of vetiver too and the sandalwood that is super woody and is almost as overpowering as the oakmoss in the dry down. I can't really smell the leather like most other people can on here though and my overall impression of the entire fragrance is that it smells like a very green and earthy tea with a hint of floracy to it. I got an impressive wear of 10 hours from Chanel's N¬∞19 and a moderate sillage that was bordering on a strong sillage. Unlike N¬∞19 Poudre, the original N¬∞19 eau de parfum can't really be worn at the office and is better suited for both day and night outings from spring to fall. It is not a wear and go type of fragrance, unlike N¬∞19 Poudre. It is also even more fully a unisex fragrance too, since it isn't as floral as Chanel N¬∞19 Poudre and also has a less intense dose of iris in it. Chanel's N¬∞19 eau de parfum is a very cool and unnaproachable smelling fragrance and is definitely not summery or warm smelling. Based on everything that I wrote above and my wear of this fragrance, I'd give it a 5/10.
author: WhiteFlowerPrincess

text: Let‚Äôs be real - No. 19 has a reputation for bitchiness. As a part time bitch myself, I saw this as more of a pro than a con, but after smelling her for myself I have to disagree with that perception. The word ‚Äúcold‚Äù gets thrown around in reference to No. 19 EDP but I think a better word is ‚Äúcool.‚Äù Chanel No 19 EDP is a pair of cool, clean hands ‚Äîpalms still tinged with the scent of leather from an expensive handbag‚Äîon warm skin. No.19 EDP is not dark green like sap or grass; it lacks chlorophyll. Have you ever been to the Lincoln Park Zoo? In its conservatory there is a room called the Fern Room, which evokes a prehistoric landscape once known to the dinosaurs. It is damp and quiet and lush with waxy green leaves and moss. It is an ancient kind of green, a bit dusty maybe. That paired with the leather and lily of the valley smells almost clinical, which may explain why so many people equate No 19 EDP with doctors or even funerals. As the opening fades and the iris gets comfortable, No. 19 EDP transforms into something lush and floral. It rewards its wearer by becoming more and more beautiful with every hour.
author: cleoclesi

text: I used to have this when I was in high school. can't recall why I got it and don't even remember the scent. Start collecting chanel perfume recently, bought a few from the exclusive and now considering collect the classic ones. tried no5, but I think I am not mature enough to appreciate it. so crystelle and no19 came to my mind and need to select one. the crystelle edt was too sharp on me, so I tried to edp one. smell gorgeous on paper but not so well on my skin. then, tried no19, both the edp and the lighter version and finally bought the classic edp. in fact, the lighter one is very nice, less sharp, more powdery, floral is more standout, yet, longevity is so bad on me. almost gone in 15 min. 19 edp is less powdery and more earthy, which is not something I prefer, but it has the crystelle vibe in a more elegant way, while better silage than the lighter version of 19.

author: Acv

text: Review for current EdP formulation, tested on a warm, humid evening: The drydown has a creamy, powdery aspect reminiscent of no.5 (it‚Äôs the ylang and iris), but here it‚Äôs cleaner and green, smoother. There is abit of floral sweetness from narcissus and rose, and the leather note is smooth and subtle. Overall, a well-blended and balanced fragrance. Extremely elegant, but warm and modest at the same time. A ‚Äòproper lady‚Äô perfume that isn‚Äôt overtly perfume-y. Reeks of status and refinement, but in an understated manner. I love it! Very comfortable to wear, but I personally would prefer this for spring, summer and early fall, the sweet floral notes come through better when the weather is warmer, I imagine it would lean more bitter-green if worn in cold weather. Perfect for office/professional use, or as a distinctive signature, or whenever you want to put your best foot forward in any formal setting. I imagine a soft-spoken doctor, or a demure professor wearing this scent as a signature‚Ä¶ she‚Äôs neat, attractive, intellectual and quietly alluring, someone loved and respected by her peers. Not a trend follower, but an individualist. This is a very feminine perfume imho, but a rare sort of femininity these days, and the kind of feminine energy I perceive from this scent is graceful, calm, mature, and down to earth. Not sexy, not ‚Äòcutesy‚Äô, not ‚Äòboss-babe‚Äô, not self-centered. Very good longevity for a daytime scent, sillage is low to moderate depending how much you spray. Nothing bitter or sharp about this scent (atleast not on my skin and in the current weather condition I‚Äôm in), it‚Äôs buttery smooth and softly powdery, a fuzzy pale green‚Ä¶you just need patience to let the grass-like top notes fade, give it 20-30 minutes to settle and you will be pleasantly surprised. I was with a friend when I tested this (another perfume lover), he thought it smelled very pleasant and luxurious but ‚Äòtoo mature‚Äô for me. He said he could see this being my scent 10-15 years from now. I didn‚Äôt care, I wanted to own it now. I fell in love as soon as the fragrance warmed on my skin, and it naturally felt like it was a part of me. The other more mainstream fragrances I had tried on that day smelled meaningless and flat in comparison.
author: marialena888m

text: Rich deep green. I have a vintage bottle and the depth is amazing
author: Zethre

text: Male review I have written a comment regarding No5, this is also a classic French female floral-chypre fragrance, subjectively to my nose. (I am not an expert in all these classifications) As a perfume connoisseur, I can recommend it for every woman who really appreciate classic French perfumery. This has nothing to do with modern commercial perfumery. This is very complex, eloquent and timeless. For lots of people, this will be also old fashioned. Well, you can call it in both ways, because it depends from what you like. Both are quite right. This is old fashioned, because this was a completely different perfumery's epoch, yet timeless, because the smell is very classical and undoubtedly French. You must not like this type of perfumery, but If you find yourself a perfume enthusiast, I strongly recommend to train the nose and try to appreciate this. This is built differently, like Chanel No5, Shalimar, YSL Rive Gauche and many others. Light and airy, white Musks (Nitro-Musks, maybe polycyclic Musks), very high concentrations of Hedione, Linalool, Ethyl-Linalool, Evernyl (oakmoss), also alfa- and beta-Ionons, Rose constituents, Vanillin, Citruses and well selected naturals. I believe, that Aldehydes can be in the construction as well like in No5. Also Cedrol or Isobutyl Quinoline (leather), Lixetone, Vetiver raw materials - I imagine it been built around some of these raw materials. This is undoubtedly bright on the start and owns powdery, woody and aromatic qualities in the dry-down. Eloquent, it can make some vintage associations to some people as well. Smells very natural, bright opening more in the sense of citruses and it definitely takes more woody direction in the dry-down, than No5 EDP. I also reminded myself about cis-3-Hexenol, as a quite strong green top-note raw material, which can potentially be here in the opening. (It smells very nice, like a freshly cut grass, I bet it works really well with citruses.) This is an elegant, day-night perfume, really suits the professional environment or special occasions. You can wear it to the theatre together with a beautiful evening outfit. It deserves to be worn more elegantly for sure. This was just my opinion, so you can always take it with the grain of salt. I really appreciate this as a man. Very beautiful. Sadly, very view people understand this type of smells nowadays. Very well said, @pygmalia.
author: Dvntex_

text: I have always loved this fragrance but allas it doesn't work on my skin. First let me start by saying i have a full 100 ml bottle I'd like to either sell or trade for something cool if anyone is interested. :) Feel free to PM. Now for the scent. I have loved this since i was young. I didn't know anyone who wore it but i did sniff it out in a department store back then and fell in love. It's very hippie chique. Very 70's. There is a lot of vetiver action going on and even though it is super classy and maybe a little shrill as people often say about this. There is a nonchalance to it. It's not all contracts and paperwork. I don't normally love green fragrances and this is extremely green. But, it has a smoky undertone that matches the overall vibe like a raspy smoker's voice coming from a fancy refined well dressed young woman. It's because of this that i realy do love it. I wish i could pull it of but it's too bitter on my skin. :( Part of me wants to keep it till i grow into it since it is either discontinued or too high in price nowadays but i feel like that is such a waist of this beauty.

text: 19 EDP, store test. 19 EDP is very beautiful emphasis of Green grass accord. The scent is cold, green and will take your heart by storm if you like a green scent. The scent is everything I could ask for. The green grass and tangy smell of galbanum. The mild floral on powdery iris. Along with smooth bed of little sweeten vanilla and dominant vetiver. I could love this, I should love this. But No, this is tiny bit brighter than La Pausa. It‚Äôs cold but still bright. La Pansa steals my heart as epitome of Cold Green Iris. author: tanaC

text: I am a vintage No19 hoarder. I had not smelled the current formula Edp until I got a bottle a year or so ago (left to age). Comparing current beautiful bottle to grey cartridge Edp from the late 90's. In the opening, the vintage is sweeter, rounder and oilier(in a good way). The current is drier and I sense pale vetiver very early on--it is more spare and open--thus I feel it would be a superb masculine. I am pleased that in the mid-to dry down they are close--still high quality. The vintage is just more lush in small ways. A more round iris rose mix and longer mid phase. In the dry down vintage becomes part of my own skin--the current is more a bit of dry green grass. J.Polge created this to be sweeter and stronger than the cologne which they phased out...cologne and vintage EDT were quite similar towards the 80's. I have big bottles of both, Edt seemed a bit more chypre maybe. The vintage extrait is the pure power chypre of legend. It makes me an Empress of the Forest--much warmer and damp oakmossy. It can be challenging--but if you are right for it...sublime If you want to go on the vintage hunt-- you will get more facets from ingredients no longer allowed or available--BUT we should thank Chanel for still making this.

text: I had to drop in and leave another really quick review about skin chemistry along with weather/seasons and wearing this particular gem. text: So, I deleted my previous review about the longevity of this scent. That doesn‚Äôt mean it doesn‚Äôt have longevity issues, because it truly does, but I found a remedy in my situation. I‚Äôm passing it on here in hopes that this may help to spark ideas for you. I was reading reviews and I came across one where the reviewer stated that in order to correct the longevity problem that they were having, they simply layered this over Molecule 01. That got me thinking. I don‚Äôt have Molecule 01 but I do have Perfect Veil in the roll on perfume oil. I thought, what do I have to lose by trying it out? I mean, nothing ventured, nothing gained, right? The worse that can happen is that I don‚Äôt like it. This morning, I decided to give it a go. First, I very lightly applied Perfect Veil, then I sprayed this over it. The result? Absolutely DIVINE! The scent is truly ethereal AND it lasted all day long. I got whiffs of it through out the day. Perfect Veil added just a touch of sweetness to it, but other than that, it didn‚Äôt alter the scent. So very glad I tried it. Edit to add: I read other reviews stating the opinion that this scent smells like it is for a cold hearted, calculating, wire mother, total bitch of a woman who is venomous, poisonous, hissing, and down right vicious who would chew you up and spit you out across a boardroom floor.. I don‚Äôt know about Gabrielle Chanel, but anyone who knows anything at all about me knows that description doesn‚Äôt fit me at all. The truth is, that is not at all what inspired the making of this scent. I‚Äôve read that this scent was inspired by Chanel‚Äôs weekends spent in the French countryside. Namely, the country house that Chanel owned, Bel Respiro. It is no wonder that fragrance in the Les Exclusifs line smells somewhat similar to this. This is an earthy scent inspired by nature and the earth, not by the kind of woman some may think Chanel was. Because of those kind of reviews, it stopped many from even trying this beautiful scent. I don‚Äôt find anything evil or cold hearted about this scent. I do, however, wonder about these reviewers‚Äô intentions when writing such reviews though. It‚Äôs one thing not liking a scent. We all have likes and dislikes, but to use tactics like expressing that only an undesirable type of person would wear such a scent is a personal attack on those who love and wear this scent. As for everyone else, don‚Äôt take just my word for it. Try it yourself and see what you think.

text: Although it is lighter than decades ago (thanks to EU and IFRA regulations, not due Chanel) you must remember NOT to start using it right after buying. It needs to sit and "marinate" in the shelve few months after transportation since it has a big impact to the composition. Also - Chanel tends to sell its fragrances while they are quite young/fresh, so ideally let it sit in the shelve few years and you feel the difference - it has turned much stronger and greener. It is not only about reformulation but also timing - this lovely gem WILL be strong and powerful in years and decades after its created and bought. No 19 EdP is classy non-sweet green mouthwatering juice. Suits perfectly (nordic European) autumn and winter and not so much warm seasons in my opinion. It needs the smell on wet soil and falling leaves to reach its full potential.

text: I am writing this review without ever experiencing the vintage original. And my first experience with 19 was the poudre version, also modern formulation. At first, I couldn‚Äôt really detect a huge difference between this and Poudre. I actually had to spray them each on their own arm to smell the differences. And while I do think they definitely have similarities, there are distinct differences between them. I do think the opening is similar, too similar for my enthusiastic novice nose to detect any noteworthy differences. But as they start to dry down, I do notice that Poudre really jumps into that soft irisy powder. The Iris is the star of the show. While 19 still has Iris, it fervently holds on to that little bit of greenery from the opening, as well as allowing some other soft florals to come forward. Here, the Iris while still present and noticeable, is a little bit more like a supporting character. These two fragrances, in my mind are definitely sisters, impossibly beautiful sisters. You think you are in the presence of the prettier one, until you put the other one on. Both absolute winners in my eye for truly remarkable fragrance. Both leave me wanting more when the scent eventually fades. One thing I don‚Äôt really get‚Ä¶ and maybe it‚Äôs because green fragrances really haven‚Äôt been considered ‚Äúin style‚Äù in my lifetime‚Ä¶ is the almost constant references to this being cold and bitchy. To me it is not. I get beauty, intelligence, confidence, and timeless sophistication. And that‚Äôs really with both 19 edp and Poudre as well.

text: A word of caution to those looking for vintage bottles‚Ä¶ I have just tried my own mid-90s bottle of EDP and it‚Äôs not how it used to be. No top notes, no fresh greenness. My no. 19 was still fairly full and carefully stored. It was a stopper bottle. Maybe a sealed spray would keep better? Maybe your own vintage bottle smells fresh and delightful?
